In addition, if eye muscles are involved, children may have droopy eyelids, ""lazy eye,"" or double vision. If mouth or throat muscles are involved, children may have difficulty speaking or swallowing. An important characteristic of myasthenia is that the weakness worsens during continuous activity, with strength returning, at least partially, after resting.
